Award.AwardTitle: FOPAM 2019: Foundations of Process Analytics and Machine learning

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is partial support of the 2019 Foundations of Process Analytics and Machine Learning (FOPAM) conference on August 5-9, 2019 in Raleigh, North Carolina. The aim of this conference is to bring together industry and academic researchers to discuss the current status and future directions in data analytics and machine learning relevant to the chemical process industries. The funds will provide support to junior faculty, postdoctoral fellows, and graduate students that may not have the financial support to attend the workshop. The conference also will include optional educational workshops.

The conference will focus on the topic of data analytics tools as applied to problems encountered in the chemical process industries. The tools can be applied to processes regardless of whether the underlying phenomena are biological, physical, or chemical. The conference will address topics in data analytics and high-throughput data process for process monitoring and diagnosis; machine learning for process and control design; computational chemistry/materials analytics; reinforcement learning as applied to process operations and control; and, synergies among process, materials, business, and supply chain data analytics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Foundations of Process Analytics and Machine learning (FOPAM 2019) brought international industry and academia together to discuss current status and future of this rapidly emerging field. Analytics and machine learning are in the early stages of transforming how chemical and biomolecular processes and products are created, operated, and assessed. Practitioners, educators, researchers, and students are eager to learn more and to understand how they can use and shape these approaches. Funding from NSF paid the travel and conference expenses for 25 young faculty, postdocs, and Ph.D. students who otherwise would have found it difficult to secure sufficient funds to participate. This investment will help them shape the future of data science for the process industries.

The FOPAM conference was preceded by two days of optional workshops and then began formally with a welcome reception and plenary by Keith Collins, the CTO of SAS Corporation, on the evening of Tuesday, August 6. For the next three days, a single track of morning and evening oral sessions of invited speakers provided their perspectives on various subtopics within the field, supplemented by question-and-answer periods and panel discussions. Wednesday and Thursday afternoons had contributed poster sessions and time for in-depth discussions. The Friday afternoon session focused on data science / data analytics education, and the conference ended that evening with a banquet and rapporteur summaries.

Intellectual merit. The conference brought together industry and university researchers and application engineers in the area of process data analytics and machine learning. The speakers and general participants assessed what has been accomplished during the past five years and examined where the field is heading. Six sessions were used to organize this exploration, each with speakers followed by a three-person moderated discussion panel:

  1. Materials design (Alán Aspuru-Guzik, U. Toronto; Paulette Clancy, Johns Hopkins Univ.)
  2. Process design (Connor W. Coley, MIT; Concepción Jiménez-González, GlaxoSmithKline)
  3. Process monitoring (Leo H. Chiang, Dow Chemical; S. Joe Qin, U. Southern California)
  4. Control design (Jay H. Lee, KAIST; Melanie Zeilinger, ETH Zurich)
  5. Business, scheduling, and supply chain (Marina Kovach, IBM; Warren Powell, Princeton Univ)
  6. Educating students and colleagues (Michael Rappa, North Carolina State Univ)

Broader impacts.  A major outcome of the conference was to identify both opportunities and technology gaps in data analytics and machine learning relevant to the process industries. The chemical process industries have seen unprecedented increases in the quantity and variety of data available for making decisions, increasing product quality, and gaining process and supply chain efficiencies. There are many unsolved theoretical and practical problems to address as the historically separate fields of machine learning, process design, product development with materials and computational chemistry, process operations, and supply-chain analysis come together.

At least as important, diverse researchers, educators, and practitioners from each field networked, learned from each other, and found new opportunities. A special issue of Computers and Chemical Engineering featured papers from the conference, which will help set directions for research and application in the process systems engineering and related areas for years to come.
